Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Teaching Practices That Support Fraction-Based Algorithmic Thinking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research and educational activities of this project focus on advancing the field in the area of fraction operation algorithm development. The goal of the research is to identify core mathematical teaching practices that engage and support students in algorithmic thinking associated with fraction operations. The project has four objectives: (1) understand and document local instructional theories and routines of practice exemplary teachers use as they engage students in algorithmic thinking for fraction operations; (2) develop a prototypical model of core routines of practice generated from exemplary teachers that support students as they engage in algorithmic thinking for fraction operations; (3) design, pilot and study the usability of the prototypical model as a professional development tool with typical teachers as they engage students in algorithmic thinking for fraction operations; and (4) identify specific core routines of practice that are shown to be productive for use with typical teachers and explore ways of disseminating them at a larger scale.

Phase One involves collaborative work with and intensive observational study of the practice of four exemplary teachers while they teach a common unit on fraction operations. Individual teacher case and cross-case examination will focus on mathematical development, use of representational modes, aspects of purposefulness in the teachers' practice, and discursive considerations and positioning of the learner. The identified local instructional theories and routines of practice that emerge will lead to the development of a prototypical model of teaching practice that engages students in algorithmic thinking for fraction operations. The prototypical model will frame the development of activities and tools to be piloted and studied with 15 typical middle grade teachers from urban and suburban districts in Phase Two. A study group focused professional development setting will be used to implement, study, and refine frameworks, activities and tools.

The product of this work will be written educational materials that can be used by other teacher educators to support the general population of teachers in this domain. These materials will identify core routines of practice associated with algorithmic thinking for fraction operations and offer activities and tools to support their development in practice. The domain of rational number has been identified as the most challenging and the most essential topic in elementary and middle school mathematics needed to succeed in higher mathematics and science. Moving forward in this area is critical in the successful preparation of students for STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research and educational activities of this project focused on advancing the field in the area of fraction operation algorithm development. The central research objective was to develop a framework of teaching practices that supports students to engage in fraction operation algorithm development using a guided reinvention approach where student problem solving is central to mathematical development. The researcher collaborated with four skillful experienced teachers to study their teaching practice while they implemented a unit where students were positioned to develop algorithms for operating with fractions through exploration with contextual problem situations where they developed models as they solved problems. These teachers did not directly explain algorithms to students. The research sought to understand common ways students were supported by teachers as they solved problems.

Research with the teachers led to the development a four-part framework of important ways the teachers interacted with and supported students’ reasoning about fraction operations without taking over the problem solving process students were engaged in. The four parts of the framework included ways teachers  (1) supported number and operation sense, (2) linked symbolism with modeling, (3) leveraged equivalence reasoning, and (4) used questioning frameworks. These four big ideas form the foundation for how to develop instructional experiences that support students to make sense of fraction operations and support algorithm development when using a guided reinvention problem solving approach to fraction operations.

The research findings then informed the design of professional development materials that include a 50 video case collection. The materials were piloted with teachers who were working to develop a practice that used a guided reinvention approach to teaching fraction operations. Because many students commonly struggle with initial ideas when modeling in contextual situations, a teacher trying this approach may initially feel uncomfortable. In turn, they may give up on using a problem-based approach and simply tell students how to operate with fractions. However, these initial but not fully developed ways of reasoning that students use are typical and should be viewed as developmentally appropriate. The video cases and questioning framework were designed to provide insight into what students commonly do and how a teacher can respond to and support students without reducing the complexity of the problem solving they are engaged in. As students grow in their ability to model problems, discuss their models and discuss the mathematical actions they carry out when modeling, the teachers in the videos begin to expand discussions to focus on symbolism in relation to models and look for opportunities which includes leveraging the use of equivalence-based reasoning as it is found in students’ initial exploratory reasoning and written work.

Teachers who participated in the professional development workshops also implemented a guided reinvention approach to fraction operation algorithm development in their classrooms. Using data from their journals, observations, student work samples, and interviews, information was collected to inform the design of the professional development materials and understand if and how the materials were impacting teaching practice. The data collected from teachers indicates that they were developing for themselves instructional theories about how students can learn to make sense of fractions, fraction operations and fraction operation algorithms. It is with a theory that they become able to successfully implement a learning trajectory that uses a guided reinvention approach to fraction operation algorithm development. When asked which parts of the professional development materials were the most beneficial to them, they most often cited the questioning frameworks and the video cases. Being able to watch of other teachers and see how their students reasoned, what was common when their students initially worked through problem-solving scenarios, and how teachers responded without out reducing the complexity of the problem solving was critical. The questioning frameworks were also important to teachers. They were something tangible that the teacher could have in front of them while they interacted with students as they solved problems.

This work aimed to support teachers in a domain that has proven to be challenging. The intellectual merit of this work comes by providing a focused analysis of how fraction algorithms can emerge in classroom settings. Fractions are one of the most complex topics to teach. The broader impact of this work is the contribution to how students’ intuitive and informal fraction reasoning can lead to more formal sophisticated knowledge about fraction operations. This work illuminated important aspects of teaching practice that supports learners when using a guided reinvention approach to fraction operations and led to the development of professional development materials that can support teachers working to grow their practice in this way.
